question_title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before May 1, 2026?
summary: North Korea has not conducted a nuclear test since September 2017 — over 8 years — despite being technically ready at Punggye-ri Tunnel No. 3 since approximately 2022. Satellite imagery as of November 2025 shows no signs of imminent test preparations. While NK has ramped up missile testing and rhetoric ahead of the Workers' Party Congress (early 2026), the historical pattern shows persistent non-testing despite readiness. A diplomatic window with potential Trump-Kim engagement in April 2026 creates additional incentive not to test. The base rate of ~2.7%/month yields ~8% for 3 months, but the 8+ year gap and lack of preparation evidence warrant significant downward adjustment. "Nothing Ever Happens" applies strongly here.

factors.description: 8+ year gap since last test (Sept 2017) despite technical readiness since 2022 — strong revealed preference for not testing
No satellite evidence of imminent test preparations at Punggye-ri as of Nov 2025 (no vehicles, instruments, cables observed)
Diplomatic window: Trump and SK President Lee seeking dialogue; possible Trump-Kim meeting April 2026 — nuclear test would close this door
NK technically prepared — Tunnel No. 3 ready, US Intel says 'probably prepared'; could test on short notice if Kim decides
Escalating rhetoric: Workers' Party Congress imminent, Kim promises plans to bolster nuclear deterrent, heavy missile testing
Historical base rate: 6 tests in 225 months = 2.7%/month, yielding ~8% for 3-month window
Worsening US-NK relations (Maduro operation condemned, NK aligning with Russia) reduces diplomatic restraint
